Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative: Research: Creating a Common Thermodynamics

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Thermodynamics and the underlying statistical picture of random molecular motions are fundamental in biology. In order to make sense of processes ranging from respiration and photosynthesis in the cell to the survival and stabilization of ecosystems students need a good understanding of energy, its conservation, its availability, and its transformation. Since biology is about the generation, maintenance, and evolution of organization and structure, the concept of information and its statistical mechanical partner, entropy, is critical. Students typically encounter energy, enthalpy, and entropy in introductory biology, chemistry, and physics classes. But the approach taken in the three disciplines can be dramatically different. Often, they make different (unstated) assumptions resulting in statements of the laws of thermodynamics that look different in different classes. This lack of consistency raises barriers to students' development of a coherent understanding of these important ideas.

In this project, we work with an interdisciplinary group of physicists, chemists, and biologists at four universities to (1) come to an agreement on a common content and representational scheme; (2) create a literature survey bringing together results about student understanding of concepts in thermodynamics from chemistry, biology, and physics education research; (3) study student understandings of and attitudes about the basic concepts of energy, entropy, diffusion, and stochastic processes; (4) create web materials including text and materials for active-learning instruction for use in an introductory physics course for biologists; and (5) create and validate an instrument to evaluate students' learning gains on these topics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
For the past few decades, the life sciences have been experiencing accelerating growth. This has been accompanied by calls from the biology and medical community for a transformation of undergraduate instruction for life science (LS) students to include a stronger focus on general scientific competency; better integration with physics, chemistry, and mathematics. While physics has traditionally been a requirement for LS students, it has been poorly integrated with their other classes. Although it may have included an occasional example from biology, it was broadly perceived, both by LS students and faculty, as having little direct relevance to the life sciences.

Our project arose out of interdisciplinary negotiations in the HHMI project, National Experiment in Undergraduate Science Education (NEXUS). From these, we learned that biology and chemistry students often had difficulty with the important topics of thermodynamics and statistical physics, topics that rely on physics but were treated peripherally or not at all in the traditional physics classes taken by LS majors. Our project was created to carry out research on how a physics course for life science students could play a more constructive role. Since NEXUS/Physics has biology, chemistry, and calculus as prerequisites, we took this class at its development site as the context for our research. The project had three threads: (1) a literature review; (2) creation of innovative curricular materials; and (3) research on student responses.

(1) Literature review: Discipline-based education research tends to be just that – discipline based. Researchers in physics or chemistry education rarely read each others' literature. We sought out education research references on teaching concepts in thermodynamics in physics, chemistry, and biology. We created a 21-page Resource Letter with 207 annotated references published in The American Journal of Physics in May 2015.

(2) Innovative curricular materials: From our interactions with biology faculty, we identified three thermodynamics and statistical mechanics concepts essential in biology and chemistry, difficult for students, and that could be helped by a physics-style approach – integrating conceptual and mathematical modeling through the use of simplified models. These were: chemical bonding, diffusion, and free energy. Since these topics are not traditionally included in an introductory physics class, we created readings and problems for homework, quizzes, and exams that explored these topics. Each required that we not only create modules that specifically covered these materials, but also that we adapt materials in more traditional parts of the class to prepare students for the modules. In discussing chemical binding between atoms, for example, it is helpful to study particular traditional potential energy problems – a skateboarded bound in a gravity well, what it means for potential energy to be negative – that are often dropped as being of peripheral interest. In discussing diffusion, the traditional discussion of directed deterministic motion has to be modified to include deterministic chaos and the value of random motion models. We created a sequence of laboratories using a high power microscope and video data capture to explore random vs. directed motion for micron-sized beads in fluids and vacuoles in an onion-skin cell. In preparation for a discussion of free energy, the standard treatment of the first law (conservation) has to be modified and more emphasis given to the statistical definition of entropy. The traditional definition of energy as "the ability to do work" and of entropy in terms of heat and temperature can mislead students in thinking about the entangled roles of entropy in what thermodynamic processes will occur spontaneously.
